title: 113_hr5215
content: The "Clatsop-Nehalem Restoration Act" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. Definitions are provided in Section 2 of the Act. The "Clatsop-Nehalem Restoration Act" provides definitions for key terms used in the legislation, including Interim Council, Member, Secretary, Tribal governing body, and Tribe. The Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon are considered as one tribe for Federal recognition, benefits, self-government, and membership roll compilation. Additionally, the Restoration Act restores Federal recognition, rights, and privileges. Federal recognition is extended to the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon, restoring their rights and privileges under Federal treaties and authorities. This bill does not affect treaty rights of other federally recognized Indian tribes. The Act grants Federal services and benefits to the tribe and its members in Oregon counties without a reservation. No hunting, fishing, or trapping rights are restored under this Act. The Act grants Federal services and benefits to the tribe and its members in Oregon counties without a reservation. No hunting, fishing, or trapping rights are restored under this Act. Additionally, no provision in the Act shall alter any property or contractual rights, or tax obligations already in place. SEC. 5. INTERIM COUNCIL. Establishment of an Interim Council composed of nine members to represent the tribe and govern until the tribal governing body convenes. Nomination and election process to select Interim Council members within specified timeframes. The Secretary shall conduct a secret ballot election to elect members of the Interim Council from nominated candidates. Approval of election results will be based on meeting nomination and election requirements. If not satisfied, another general council meeting will be called to nominate candidates and hold a new election within specified timeframes. The Interim Council, established through a secret ballot election, has limited powers under the Act. It has the authority to receive grants and enter contracts for Federal services or benefits. The Council will terminate once the tribal governing body convenes, except as specified in subsection (d). The Secretary ensures members are notified of meetings and elections at least 10 days in advance. The Interim Council, established through a secret ballot election, has limited powers under the Act. It can receive grants, enter contracts for Federal services, and bind the tribal governing body for up to 6 months. Vacancies on the Interim Council must be filled through a general council meeting and election, with notice provided to members at least 10 days in advance. SEC. 6. TRIBAL CONSTITUTION AND BYLAWS; TRIBAL GOVERNING BODY. The Interim Council must prepare and adopt a tribal constitution and bylaws within 6 months. After adoption, the Council can request the Secretary to schedule an election to approve or disapprove the constitution and bylaws. The Interim Council must prepare and adopt a tribal constitution and bylaws within 6 months. Not less than 30 days before any election, a copy of the proposed constitution and bylaws shall be sent to each member. Majority vote of those actually voting is necessary for adoption. If the majority does not approve the adoption of the proposed tribal constitution and bylaws, the Interim Council will prepare a new constitution within 6 months. An election will be held to approve the new proposal. The Interim Council will conduct an election within 120 days of tribal approval to elect the tribal governing body under the new constitution and bylaws, with absentee and write-in voting allowed. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP ROLLS; VOTING RIGHTS OF MEMBER. The membership roll of the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes is established and open. Eligibility criteria include direct descent from a Clatsop or Nehalem Tillamook Indian on tribal rolls from 1906 or being found eligible by the Portland, Oregon, Area Office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Any person who descends from signers of treaties between the United States and the Clatsop Tribe and the Nehalem Band of the Tillamooks at Tansy Point in 1851, or can document their direct descent, is eligible for membership in the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes. Any person eligible for membership in the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes must document direct descent from Clatsop or Nehalem Tillamook Indians, be a descendant of Hobsonville Community members, or be born to a tribe member. Membership is governed by the constitution and bylaws after the first tribal governing body election. Dual membership in another federally recognized tribe is not allowed, and verification procedures are in place before the interim council election. Before the election of the Interim Council members, descendancy verification for enrollment and voting rights must be done before the Secretary. After the Interim Council election but before the tribal governing body election, descendancy and age verification can be appealed to the Secretary if excluded from the tribe's membership roll. After the first election of the tribal governing body, the constitution and bylaws will govern membership verification. The Secretary will finalize any appeals regarding membership within 90 days. The Secretary will publish the membership roll at least 60 days before the election. The Secretary will publish a certified membership roll of the tribe before the election, including names of enrolled individuals. Members 18 years and older have voting rights, including attending meetings, nominating candidates, running for office, and voting in elections. The Secretary has the authority to create necessary regulations for implementing the provisions of this Act.
